channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Cyprus banks reopen with tough curbs
item.description: Banks in Cyprus reopen after a two-week closure sparked by negotiations over an EU-IMF bailout, but withdrawals are being tightly controlled.

item.title: Mandela 'responding to treatment'
item.description: Former South African President Nelson Mandela is "responding positively" to treatment for the recurrence of a lung infection, the presidency says.

item.title: Newtown gunman 'had weapons arsenal'
item.description: The young man who killed 27 people in a massacre in Newtown, Connecticut, owned an arsenal of weapons and ammunition, court papers show.

item.title: 'Failings' in Lakanal fire deaths
item.description: Lakanal House fire victim Catherine Hickman could have escaped to safety via a communal balcony, an inquest hears.

item.title: Top officer rapped over Hillsborough
item.description: Sir Norman Bettison would have a "case to answer for gross misconduct" for his actions following the publication of a report into the Hillsborough disaster, the IPCC finds.

item.title: Pistorius granted freedom to travel
item.description: South African athlete Oscar Pistorius, facing a murder charge, can travel overseas to compete under certain conditions, after contesting bail terms.

item.title: MP Joyce will not face charges
item.description: Scotland Yard says MP Eric Joyce, who was held by police after an alleged drunken brawl at a bar in the House of Commons, will not be facing charges.

item.title: NZ police seek Ryder attack motive
item.description: New Zealand police are trying to find a motive for the assault on cricketer Jesse Ryder, who is in a medically induced coma after being attacked in Christchurch.

item.title: Boris Berezovsky 'had neck ligature'
item.description: An inquest into the death of Russian tycoon Boris Berezovsky hears he was discovered lying on his bathroom floor with a "ligature around his neck".

item.title: Thousands leaving UK for Easter
item.description: Thousands of Britons are expected to travel abroad for Easter following the freezing and snowy weather.

item.title: BBC staff go on strike over cuts
item.description: BBC journalists and technicians are holding a 12-hour strike in a continuing row over job cuts and allegations of bullying.

item.title: Queen gives coins at Maundy service
item.description: The Queen distributes coins to people who have worked hard for their community at the Royal Maundy service held in Oxford.

item.title: Malala Yousafzai signs $3m book deal
item.description: Pakistani teenager Malala Yousafzai, who was shot in the head by the Taliban in October, signs a book deal worth about $3m.

item.title: Louvre is most visited venue of 2012
item.description: The Louvre in Paris tops the list of the most visited art museums of 2012, according to the Art Newspaper.

item.title: US growth is faster than expected
item.description: The US economy grew at a faster than expected 0.4% in the fourth quarter, the Department of Commerce says, but the overall picture remains sluggish.

item.title: Oil firms invest £330m in Atlantic
item.description: Major oil companies announce plans which they hope will boost production from the UK's biggest oilfield.

item.title: No 10 moves 'to bolster MP links'
item.description: David Cameron moves John Hayes from energy minister to be his parliamentary adviser "to bolster" links with backbench Tories.

item.title: Ahmed apology over Jewish claims
item.description: Lord Ahmed has apologised "completely and unreservedly" for blaming Jewish-owned media organisations for his imprisonment for dangerous driving.

item.title: Synchrotron yields 'safer' vaccine
item.description: British scientists develop a new way to create an entirely synthetic vaccine which does not rely on using live infectious virus, meaning it is much safer.

item.title: Consultants warn of A&E 'meltdown'
item.description: Consultant speak out and warn that accident and emergency departments are at the point of meltdown with patients are dying as a result.

item.title: GCSE changes 'work against girls'
item.description: Changes to GCSE examinations in England could be to the disadvantage of girls and see their results fall, teachers warn.

item.title: Warning of 'teacher shortage crisis'
item.description: Pupils in England could be taught in bigger classes and by unqualified staff, as schools will need an extra 15,000 teachers, Labour claims.

item.title: Bitcoin miners hit back at botnets
item.description: Bitcoin miners are hitting back at cyber-thieves attempting to cash in on the popularity of the virtual currency.

item.title: 'Disruptive' Ouya console launches
item.description: A new crowdfunded games console, which some experts believe could heavily disrupt the games industry, has begun shipping to its first customers.

item.title: Sea hares' sticky defence uncovered
item.description: Sea hares fool hungry predators with a sticky secretion that deactivates their sense of smell, scientists say.

item.title: Pesticides 'damage brains of bees'
item.description: Commonly used pesticides are damaging the brains of honey bees and affecting their ability to learn, two studies suggest.

item.title: Rolling Stones to play Glastonbury
item.description: The Rolling Stones are named as one of the three headline acts for the 2013 Glastonbury Festival, the first time they have played the event.

item.title: Bollywood star to 'return to prison'
item.description: Bollywood actor Sanjay Dutt says he will return to prison for his connection with the 1993 Mumbai blasts.

item.title: What is 'ungoogleable'?
item.description: The word "ungoogleable" has been removed from a list of new Swedish words after a trademark spat. But what does it mean?

item.title: The bikes for people who don't cycle
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of electric bikes are sold in Germany and Holland every year, so why have they failed to catch on in the UK?

item.title: Haye aiming for world title again
item.description: Former WBA heavyweight champion David Haye targets a world title as he returns on 29 June in Manchester.

item.title: Wilshere to return in two weeks
item.description: Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger says Jack Wilshere will be given an extra week to recover from an ankle injury.

item.title: Vettel and Webber row 'settled'
item.description: Red Bull boss Helmut Marko says the row between Mark Webber and Sebastian Vettel is now "settled".

item.title: Lendl wants Murray rankings rise
item.description: Andy Murray's hopes of winning the French Open will improve if he can become world number two, says coach Ivan Lendl.

item.title: Heavyweight Whyte's drugs ban upheld
item.description: British heavyweight Dillian Whyte will serve a two-year ban after testing positive for methylhexaneamine.

item.title: Ennis given freedom of home city
item.description: Olympic gold medallist Jessica Ennis is granted the freedom of her home city of Sheffield in a private ceremony.

item.title: Life for man who murdered parents
item.description: A man who shot his parents after trying to kill them by driving a car into a canal is sentenced to life.

item.title: Two in hospital after gas explosion
item.description: Two pensioners are taken to hospital following a gas explosion in Callander, which completely demolished a house.

item.title: Russell warns of 'coasting schools'
item.description: Scotland's education secretary raises concern over "coasting" schools which are not ambitious enough for their pupils.

item.title: Committee meets over farmers' plight
item.description: The assembly agriculture committee holds an emergency meeting to assess the damage caused to NI farms by the severe weather.

item.title: Security alert at city roundabout
item.description: The Broadway roundabout in west Belfast has been closed due to a security alert.

item.title: Jones steps into neonatal care row
item.description: First Minister Carwyn Jones says the Welsh government is preparing to look at "another model" for providing acute neonatal care in north Wales.

item.title: Contract for long-awaited bypass
item.description: The contractor for the long-awaited Newtown bypass in Powys is announced by the Welsh government, 40 years after the first calls for a relief road.

item.title: Deaths as gang attacks Kenya casino
item.description: At least seven people are killed in a Kenyan coastal town during a raid on a casino by a machete-wielding gang of separatists, police say.

item.title: Arrests as Egypt internet cable cut
item.description: Three divers have been arrested while trying to sever an undersea internet cable off the port city of Alexandria, Egyptian authorities say.

item.title: Burmese president warns 'extremists'
item.description: Burmese President Thein Sein warns that he will if necessary use force to stop 'religious extremists' from fomenting hatred.

item.title: Thailand begins southern peace talks
item.description: Thailand begins peace talks in Kuala Lumpur with representatives of Muslim insurgents aimed at curbing violence in the south.

item.title: Pope's Maundy message of humility
item.description: Pope Francis will wash inmates' feet in a youth detention centre on Thursday, part of a papal calendar of events in the run-up to Easter.

item.title: Sarkozy judge receives death threat
item.description: The lead examining magistrate in a corruption case against former French President Nicolas Sarkozy gets a death threat in the post.

item.title: Rio 2016 stadium escapes demolition
item.description: The Joao Havelange stadium, which was due to host the Rio 2016 Olympics, will not be demolished, despite structural problems that led to its closure.

item.title: Brazil eyes doctor's link to deaths
item.description: Some 300 deaths at a Brazilian hospital are being studied for possible links to a doctor already charged with seven murders.

item.title: Mortars hit Damascus University
item.description: Mortar fire hits the University of Damascus, killing 15 students and wounding several others, Syrian state media say.

item.title: Court acquits 21 Bahraini medics
item.description: Twenty-one medics arrested at a hospital during anti-government protests in Bahrain two years ago have their convictions quashed.

item.title: US cinema killer 'may plead guilty'
item.description: Lawyers for the man accused of killing 12 cinema-goers last July in Aurora, Colorado, say he is prepared to plead guilty to avoid the death penalty.

item.title: US justices criticise anti-gay law
item.description: A US law that defines marriage as between a man and a woman only is sharply criticised by Supreme Court justices during a landmark hearing.

item.title: Mozambique: Life in pictures
item.description: Ariadne Van Zandbergen explores this changing country

item.title: Your pictures: On the edge
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme On the edge

item.title: Day in pictures: 27 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 27 March

item.title: In pictures: Losing Ground
item.description: Communities in Cambodia fight for their right to land

item.title: Day in pictures: 26 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 26 March

item.title: In pictures: Shifting Perspectives
item.description: Representation of people with Down’s syndrome

item.title: Day in pictures: 25 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 25 March

item.title: In Pictures: Rowena Cade's theatre
item.description: The Minack Theatre prepares for its new season

item.title: VIDEO: Scottish Parliament
item.description: Live coverage from the Scottish Parliament.

item.title: VIDEO: Antiquity thieves' tunnels uncovered
item.description: Since the revolution in Egypt, large holes have been appearing in the ground close to places of archaeological significance, such as the Great Pyramids at Giza.

item.title: VIDEO: US landslide prompts evacuations
item.description: A large landslide has damaged houses and prompted evacuations in Washington State in the US.

item.title: VIDEO: Family 'numb' after Seddon murders
item.description: A man who shot his parents dead after trying to kill them by driving a car into a canal has been jailed for life.

item.title: VIDEO: Plague of locusts in Madagascar
item.description: A severe plague of locusts has infested about half of Madagascar, threatening crops and raising concerns about food shortages, a UN agency says.

item.title: VIDEO: Pistorius may travel outside South Africa
item.description: South African athlete Oscar Pistorius, who is charged with murdering his girlfriend, will be allowed to travel after successfully challenging the terms of his bail.

item.title: VIDEO: Prince William on RAF rescue duties
item.description: A new BBC documentary series captures Prince William, or Flight Lieutenant Wales, as never seen before - in his role as a search and rescue pilot based on Anglesey.

item.title: AUDIO: John Humphrys goes to Glastonbury
item.description: The Today presenter hears from Glastonbury Festival founder Michael Eavis

item.title: VIDEO: Lamp post hits Chinese bus driver
item.description: A bus driver in China narrowly evaded death after a lamp post smashed through the windscreen of his vehicle.

item.title: The rise of online STI dating
item.description: Online dating for people with herpes and other STIs

item.title: Interactive video: Synthetic viruses
item.description: Could they herald better vaccines, asks Fergus Walsh

item.title: The Afghan 'green-on-blue' attacker seen as a hero
item.description: Why angry young Afghan murdered US troops

item.title: Pleasures and perils of open-plan offices
item.description: Why do so many of us have to work in open-plan offices?

item.title: Polar bears: An uncertain future
item.description: Polar bears face uncertain future as Arctic melts

item.title: Has drawing been erased from animation?
item.description: Have drawing skills been erased from films?

item.title: Golden age for Egypt tomb raiders
item.description: How tomb raiders benefit from Egypt's revolution

item.title: Where have the player-managers gone?
item.description: Where have English football's player-managers gone?

item.title: Miliband joins list of 'nearly men'
item.description: Why didn't David Miliband quite make it to the top?

item.title: Australia PM backs UK monarch role
item.description: Republican and monarch find common ground
